title: BMW puts it foot on the accelerator for self-driving cars
text:
And what is the story with the technology? The Vision M is built around a strong and light carbon-fibre monocoque, like the current i8 model. It will be able to drive for up to 100 kilometres on its batteries, which makes it suitable for use in the zero emission zones many believe will soon come to major European CBDs. However, when pushed hard, the Vision M Next will use its electric system and turbocharged four-cylinder petrol engine in tandem to unleash 441kW. Top speed is said to be 300km/h, and acceleration from rest to 100km/h takes a mere three seconds.

The Vision M is a message to the driver, for people who love driving and are afraid they are going to lose that. — Adrian van Hooydonk, BMW Group

“We are not dogmatic,” says van Hooydonk. “We are not saying that everything will be electric only. For the next 10 years plug-in hybrids will play a big role, because if you want to go fast and you want to go far, and to also drive free of emissions in the city, then a hybrid system is probably the best way to go.”

The 55-year-old Dutchman insists the driver assistance systems and artificial intelligence built into future BMW sports cars will not take the driving sensation away, but improve it. “The Vision M is a message to the driver, for people who love driving and are afraid they are going to lose that.”

He says the M1 remains a BMW icon, while the i8 paved the way for plug-in hybrid performance cars, which are becoming increasingly common. “It is unavoidable to reference those two cars when you do something new.”

BMW is also preparing to take high-performance motorcycles into the electric age and has unveiled the Vision DC Roadster concept. Edgar Heinrich, the head designer at BMW’s Motorrad motorcycle division, stresses the challenge of a fully electric motorcycle. “There are two big questions,” he says. “How do you make an electric motorcycle emotional – they are usually perceived more like a washing machine or drier – and how do you make a BMW out of it?”

The Vision DC Roadster concept motorcycle.

The main problem, he says, is that “a bike is basically defined by the engine, and with an electric engine you don’t have any mechanical icon any more”. In an electric motorcycle, the batteries – which provide little visual interest – take up far more space than the compact electrical motor.

Since it lacks the engine and fuel tank, Heinrich says they created a stance with a “clear front wheel orientation” and have drawn attention to “little jewels”, such as the milled aluminium trellis frame and the intricate eco-skeleton around where the fuel tank would otherwise be.

Advertisement

“We wanted to have a lightweight feeling because electric bikes look a bit heavy … a sort of floating look that gives it a light, nimble feel. It has to speak to your guts, which is always important.”

Many BMW motorcycles are immediately recognised by their distinctive boxer-twin engines, with the exposed cylinders jutting out to aid cooling. “You need radiators on an electric bike too,” Heinrich says, “and it makes sense to put them out in the airstream.”

The radiators actually move out slightly when the bike is started. The result is a thoroughly modern reimagining of the boxer engine profile, suggesting to enthusiasts that although radically different, the brand’s heritage values have been maintained. It helps, of course, that an electric motor delivers its full torque immediately and provides what Heinrich calls “breathtaking acceleration”.

The trio of BMW “Next” concepts, from left: Vision Next 100, Vision M Next and iNext.

As well as linking the old and new, there is the challenge of north, south east and west. This is reflected in one of the more controversial aspects of contemporary BMW design – the way its car grilles are getting so much larger, particularly in the updated 7-Series limousine and the new flagship SUV, the X7.

“Recently we have offered various sizes and shapes of grilles,” says van Hooydonk. “On an 8-Series coupe it is horizontal, quite flat; on an X7, quite tall. Then on the 7-Series we’ve changed the grille dramatically, and people notice that.”

Did the designers realise it would be polarising? “Yes, we suspected that. But for the customers in the most relevant markets there was not enough presence, so we decided to do something fairly dramatic.”

In Europe and Australia, a 7-Series customer wants to go unnoticed, with a sort of stealth vehicle. In Asia and the US, it is the opposite. — Adrian van Hooydonk, BMW Group

He said the 7-Series is the most difficult car when it comes to pleasing the tastes of all markets. “In Europe and Australia, a 7-Series customer wants to go unnoticed, with a sort of stealth vehicle, no chrome. In Asia and the US it is quite the opposite, so it is impossible to do all of that in one car.”

The good news, says van Hooydonk, is that the tastes of the global markets are growing closer together “and I think for the future that will make our job a little easier”.

As for the not-much-less controversial X7 frontal treatment, van Hooydonk says when vehicles become bigger, the grille can also grow with them. “If you ask me, the X7 grille is right for the size of the car.”

The author visited BMW headquarters in Munich as a guest of the company.

The heritage issue of LUXURY is out on Friday, September 6 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow LUXURY on Instagram.
description: The German company is setting out to prove its sport cars and motorcycles will still be all about the driving and riding experience.
